conclusion: To determine whether the particle has returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark, we need to calculate the displacement of the particle over the given time interval using the velocity-time (v-t) graph.
The displacement is the area under the velocity-time graph.
From 0 to 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s.

premise: The velocity is constant at 2 m/s from 0 to 1 second.
conclusion: The area under the graph is a rectangle with a height of 2 m/s and a width of 1 s.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s.

premise: The velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s from 1 to 2 seconds.
conclusion: The area under the graph is a triangle.

premise: Base of the triangle = 1 s (from t = 1 to t = 2) and Height of the triangle = 2 m/s (from v = 2 to v = 0)
conclusion: Area = 0.5 × base × height = 0.5 × 1 s × 2 m/s = 1 m.
From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s.

premise: The velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s from 2 to 3 seconds.
conclusion: The area under the graph is a triangle.

premise: Base of the triangle = 1 s (from t = 2 to t = 3) and Height of the triangle = 2 m/s (from v = 0 to v = -2)
conclusion: Area = 0.5 × base × height = 0.5 × 1 s × 2 m/s = 1 m.

premise: Since the velocity is negative, the area represents a displacement in the opposite direction.
Displacement from 0 to 1 second = 2 m, Displacement from 1 to 2 seconds = 1 m, Displacement from 2 to 3 seconds = -1 m.
conclusion: Total displacement = 2 m + 1 m - 1 m = 2 m.
The particle has not returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark.
